pageProps.contentHtml:
normal families, Urysohn subsequence principle

Let {fn}n∈N\set{f_n}_{n\in\N}{fn​}n∈N​ be a sequence of holomorphic functions on D\DD satisfying ∣fn(z)∣≤1\abs{f_n\p{z}} \leq 1∣fn​(z)∣≤1 for all z∈Dz \in \Dz∈D and n∈Nn \in \Nn∈N. Let A⊆DA \subseteq \DA⊆D be the set of all z∈Dz \in \Dz∈D for which the limit lim⁡n→∞fn(z)\lim_{n\to\infty} f_n\p{z}limn→∞​fn​(z) exists. Show that if AAA has an accumulation point in D\DD, then there exists a holomorphic function fff on D\DD such that fn→ff_n \to ffn​→f locally uniformly on D\DD as n→∞n \to \inftyn→∞.
Solution.

Let K⊆DK \subseteq \DK⊆D be a compact set, and let δ=d(K,Dc)2>0\delta = \frac{d\p{K, \D^\comp}}{2} > 0δ=2d(K,Dc)​>0. By the Cauchy integral formula, for any z∈Kz \in Kz∈K, we have B(0,δ)‾⊆D\cl{B\p{0, \delta}} \subseteq \DB(0,δ)​⊆D and so

∣fn′(z)∣≤12π∫∂B(0,δ)∣fn(ζ)∣∣ζ−z∣2 d∣ζ∣≤12π∥fn∥L∞δ22πδ=1δ≕MK.\abs{f_n'\p{z}} \leq \frac{1}{2\pi} \int_{\partial B\p{0,\delta}} \frac{\abs{f_n\p{\zeta}}}{\abs{\zeta - z}^2} \,\diff\abs{\zeta} \leq \frac{1}{2\pi} \frac{\norm{f_n}_{L^\infty}}{\delta^2} 2\pi \delta = \frac{1}{\delta} \eqqcolon M_K.∣fn′​(z)∣≤2π1​∫∂B(0,δ)​∣ζ−z∣2∣fn​(ζ)∣​d∣ζ∣≤2π1​δ2∥fn​∥L∞​​2πδ=δ1​=:MK​.

Thus, by the fundamental theorem of calculus, given any z,w∈Kz, w \in Kz,w∈K, we have

∣f(z)−f(w)∣≤∫zw∣f′(ζ)∣ d∣ζ∣≤MK∣z−w∣,\abs{f\p{z} - f\p{w}} \leq \int_z^w \abs{f'\p{\zeta}} \,\diff\abs\zeta \leq M_K\abs{z - w},∣f(z)−f(w)∣≤∫zw​∣f′(ζ)∣d∣ζ∣≤MK​∣z−w∣,

i.e., {fn}n\set{f_n}_n{fn​}n​ is equicontinuous on KKK and uniformly bounded on MKM_KMK​, so we may apply Arzelà-Ascoli on any compact subset of D\DD. In particular, by taking K=B(0,1−1n)‾K = \cl{B\p{0, 1 - \frac{1}{n}}}K=B(0,1−n1​)​ and using a diagonal argument, we find a subsequence {fnk}k\set{f_{n_k}}_k{fnk​​}k​ which converges locally uniformly to some fff on all of D\DD. Since each fnf_nfn​ is holomorphic, it follows that fff is itself holomorphic (e.g., by Morera's theorem). We will show that fn→ff_n \to ffn​→f locally uniformly itself by showing that any subsequence has a further subsequence which converges locally uniformly to fff.

Let {fnk}k\set{f_{n_k}}_k{fnk​​}k​ be subsequence which converges locally uniformly to some ggg and let K⊆DK \subseteq \DK⊆D be compact. Notice that by pointwise convergence on AAA, we see that

g(z)=lim⁡n→∞fn(z)=f(z),g\p{z} = \lim_{n\to\infty} f_n\p{z} = f\p{z},g(z)=n→∞lim​fn​(z)=f(z),

i.e., fff and ggg are two holomorphic functions which agree on a set containing a limit point, so f=gf = gf=g on all of D\DD, i.e., {fnk}k\set{f_{n_k}}_k{fnk​​}k​ converges locally uniformly to fff.

Now let {fnk}k\set{f_{n_k}}_k{fnk​​}k​ be any subsequence. By Arzelà-Ascoli, it admits a further subsequence which converges locally uniformly, and by the previous paragraph, this subsequence converges to fff. Thus, every subsequence of {fn}n\set{f_n}_n{fn​}n​ admits a further subsequence which converges locally uniformly to fff, and so fn→ff_n \to ffn​→f locally uniformly.

Indeed, if this were not the case, then there exist K⊆DK \subseteq \DK⊆D compact and ε>0\epsilon > 0ε>0 such that for each n≥1n \geq 1n≥1, we obtain zk∈Kz_k \in Kzk​∈K and nkn_knk​ so that {fnk}k\set{f_{n_k}}_k{fnk​​}k​ is a subsequence and ∣fnk(zk)−f(zk)∣≥ε\abs{f_{n_k}\p{z_k} - f\p{z_k}} \geq \epsilon∣fnk​​(zk​)−f(zk​)∣≥ε. But clearly any further subsequence cannot converge uniformly to fff on KKK, which is a contradiction. This completes the proof.
